user_input: What does Malit Jing do at WSO2 and how does he contribute to AI strategy?
reference_contexts: ["So I am both the track lead and the I'm a speaker as well. So looks like I have to introduce myself but I won't spend a lot of time on the introduction. So my name is Malit Jing. I'm the VP of research and VP of AI at WSO2. So I've been with WSO2 for nearly 10 years. I'm a both distributed systems and AI guy. So worked a lot on the distributor systems in the early part of the career. Now sort of moved into uh AI um so I worked very closely with the product teams and also helped to define the AI strategy for WSO2. So we have two sides of our AI strategy. One is we called AI for code which is about the developer experience and how we you know bring capabilities features into our products to improve the develop experience of the users who are using our products. The other one is we called code for AI and that is all about building AI applications. What are the abstractions that are needed to build these AI apps? So that is the AI gateways you know IM agents and so on right so let's get uh started um I think you can start the clock so um so what I'm going to be talking about today is the evolution of AI agents not the evaluation evolution right so I thought it would be a good idea to have a summary like this uh then I will link to uh today's uh presentation. So this is an art summary of an article that was uh why that one works right >> this one. >> Yeah. Okay. Summary of an article that was published by McKenzie. Uh uh so I've uh let me take you through these."]
reference: Malit Jing is the VP of research and VP of AI at WSO2. He has been with WSO2 for nearly 10 years and has worked extensively on distributed systems and AI. He works closely with product teams and helps define the AI strategy for WSO2, which includes 'AI for code' to improve the developer experience and 'code for AI' for building AI applications.

reference: At WSO2, the integration of AI strategies enhances the developer experience through the 'AI for code' initiative, which focuses on bringing capabilities and features into products to improve the user experience for developers. This involves incorporating AI to streamline tool connectivity and access functionalities within developer platforms. Additionally, the 'code for AI' strategy focuses on building AI applications, which involves creating necessary abstractions like AI gateways and IM agents. These strategies collectively support data integration by utilizing retrieval augmented generation (RAG) to ground responses with data from a knowledge base, thereby enhancing the proactiveness and autonomy of AI agents in performing actions independently.

reference: The A2A protocol facilitates agent-to-agent communication by standardizing the communication transport protocol, specifically using JSNRPC, and providing features such as the agent card, which includes details like name, description, URL, version, skills, and ID. This allows agents to understand the skills and data formats required for interaction. MCP, on the other hand, plays a role in standardizing AI applications by providing a framework that supports the integration and functionality of AI applications, ensuring that they can operate effectively within developer platforms.

Additionally, hardware innovation is discussed as a means to improve scalability and support real-time interactions, addressing issues like transparency and explainability in AI models. These discussions highlight the importance of both software and hardware advancements in overcoming current challenges in AI development.

reference: The A2A protocol facilitates agent-to-agent communication by standardizing the communication process through a transport protocol known as JSNRPC. It includes features such as the 'agent card,' which provides information like name, description, URL, version, skills, and ID of an agent, allowing other agents to understand and interact with it effectively. A2A plays a crucial role in the evolution of multi-agent systems by providing a standardized method for communication as agents become more capable and autonomous. This evolution is part of a broader trend where single agents are no longer sufficient, necessitating the development of multi-agent communication protocols like A2A.

user_input: How does the SO2 internal developer platform facilitate the software development lifecycle within VS Code, and what role does it play in connecting agents to various tools?
reference_contexts: ["<1-hop>\n\nSO2's internal developer platform. Right. So and then we've gone and uh you know uh installed that one in VS code. So it is basically driving the full you know life cycle of this software development. So here what happens is you go we have gone and develop a service. Okay it's gone that's fine u and you want to uh then push this service to coro right so it then does various tests. Have I logged into Coro? Does the project exist? If not, let's create it and does the component exist? If not, let's create the component. So, and then, you know, let's get the build pack and so on. So, it takes you through all of those steps and finally it will push to Coro and then you can deploy it there. Right? So, so we've gone from Genai to rags to agents to MCP. Now let's get to uh multi-agent systems, right? So if you take a look at a single agent, yes, they work fine. So what happens is the systems become bigger and bigger, right? So the then you want you get to a situation where you need to connect this agent to more and more tools. This works actually for many use cases."]
reference: The SO2 internal developer platform is integrated into VS Code to drive the full lifecycle of software development. It allows developers to develop a service and then push it to Coro, where it performs various tests such as checking if the user is logged into Coro, verifying the existence of the project and component, and creating them if necessary. It also involves obtaining the build pack and ultimately deploying the service to Coro. As systems grow larger, the platform supports the connection of agents to more tools, which is beneficial for many use cases, thereby streamlining tool connectivity and access functionalities within the development environment.

reference: The A2A protocol facilitates agent-to-agent communication in multi-agent systems by providing a standardized way for agents to communicate, addressing issues such as understanding the skills of other agents, data formats, and data types. MCP complements this by standardizing how AI applications, not necessarily agents, communicate with tools. This standardization is crucial as single agents are not sufficient, and multi-agent systems require effective communication protocols like A2A to function efficiently.
